content: Title 18, United States Code, is amended by inserting a new chapter 212 regarding criminal offenses committed outside the United States by persons accompanying the Armed Forces. Title 18, United States Code, is amended by inserting a new chapter 212 regarding criminal offenses committed outside the United States by persons accompanying the Armed Forces. Section 3261 addresses criminal offenses committed by individuals serving with or employed by the Armed Forces outside the US, subjecting them to similar punishment as if the offense had occurred within US jurisdiction. The new chapter 212 of Title 18, United States Code, addresses criminal offenses committed outside the US by individuals accompanying the Armed Forces. It states that offenders may face similar punishment as if the offense had occurred within US jurisdiction. Additionally, courts-martial, military commissions, and other military tribunals maintain concurrent jurisdiction over such offenders and offenses. Prosecution under this section is prohibited if a foreign government has already prosecuted the individual for the same offense, unless approved by the Attorney General or Deputy Attorney General of the United States. The Secretary of Defense may authorize law enforcement personnel in the Department of Defense to arrest individuals outside the US if there is probable cause of criminal conduct. The arrested person will be handed over to US civilian authorities for judicial proceedings unless certain conditions are met. The Secretary of Defense can authorize law enforcement personnel to arrest individuals outside the US with probable cause of criminal conduct. The person can be delivered to foreign authorities under section 3262 or face charges under chapter 47 of title 10. Delivery to foreign countries is possible if requested for trial under their laws and authorized by a treaty or international agreement. The Secretary of Defense can authorize law enforcement personnel to arrest individuals outside the US with probable cause of criminal conduct. Foreign officials designated by the Secretary will handle the apprehension, detention, and removal of persons under this chapter. Regulations governing these processes must be uniform throughout the Department of Defense. Persons accompanying the Armed Forces outside the United States are defined as dependents of military or civilian personnel residing with them abroad, who are not nationals of the host nation. The table of chapters in part II of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding a new item after chapter 211. SEC. 2. MILITARY JUSTICE ACTIONS. 212. Criminal Offenses Committed Outside the United States 3261. The Director of the FBI is defined in this section. Military departments must provide records of penal actions to the Director upon discharge. Individuals convicted of sexual crimes must provide DNA samples before military discharge. The military department must provide DNA samples from members to the FBI for inclusion in the CODIS system.
